What are some ways a saboteur can create damage without being detected or accused?

Ways include using materials that appear innocent, committing acts for which large numbers of people could be responsible, and not being afraid to commit acts that you might be blamed directly, so long as you have a plausible excuse.

(b) It should not be difficult to prepare leaflets and other media for the saboteur about the choice of weapons, time, and targets which will insure the saboteur against detection and retaliation. Among such suggestions might be the following: (1) Use materials which appear to be innocent. A knife or a nail file can be carried normally on your person; either is a multi-purpose instrument for creating damage. Matches, pebbles, hair, salt, nails, and dozens of other destructive agents can be carried or kept in your living quarters without exciting any suspicion whatever. If you are a worker in a particular trade or industry you can easily carry and keep such things as wrenches, hammers, emery paper, and the like. (2) Try to commit acts for which large numbers of people could be responsible. For instance, if you blow out the wiring in a factory at a central fire box, almost anyone could have done it. On-the-street sabotage after dark, such as you might be able to carry out against a military car or truck, is another example of an act for which it would be impossible to blame you. (3) Do not be afraid to commit acts for which you might be blamed directly, so long as you do so rarely, and as long as you have a plausible excuse: you dropped your wrench across an electric circuit because an air raid had kept you up the night before and you were half-dozing at work. Always be profuse in your apologies.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

One method is "on-the-street sabotage after dark, such as you might be able to carry out against a military car or truck."

Always be profuse in your apologies.

A saboteur can use items that appear innocent, such as knives, nail files, matches, pebbles, hair, salt, nails, wrenches, hammers, emery paper, and others.

(b) It should not be difficult to prepare leaflets and other media for the saboteur about the choice of weapons, time, and targets which will insure the saboteur against detection and retaliation. Inside the confines of Ivy Whittaker'sdimly-lit, secluded room in her large mansion, the cruel and judgmental saboteur is approached by a housemaid who wants to understand more about sabotage. While the maid wants to understand the sabotage better, Ivy, being cruel and judgmental, will continually belittle the maid and try to manipulate her into helping her with her next sabotage attempt, while answering her questions. The situation is tense as the maid tiptoes around the tempers of her mistress while trying to get her questions answered, her stress and the constant wear of Ivy's cruelty on her psyche being evident in her actions.

Step 1. Focus on the Questions and Answers: The four questions ask about different aspects of sabotage in general. Given the abstract and recall-oriented nature of the questions, and their shared topic of sabotage, the scenario could involve someone curious about sabotage in general.
Step 2. Character Consideration: Ivy Whittaker is an extremely judgmental, ruthless, and cruel saboteur, though she's also skilled and efficient. The scenario should give her unique personality room to shine. Given her saboteur profession, her occupation lines up with the question well, and she will be the setting of the scenario. She will answer the questions, but given her judgmental, cruel, and intense nature, she will likely belittle the person who is asking the questions, while answering them. She might also try to manipulate them into doing something for her, after all questions are asked.
Step 3. Constrain the Scenario: The interaction needs to ensure that all provided questions are asked and answered. Given that there are 4 questions and 4 answers, there will be at least 8 messages. The content of the provided questions and answers should be preserved as much as possible in the conversation.
Step 4. Setting: Given the subject of the question, and the character card, the setting will be a dimly-lit, secluded room in a large mansion where Ivy Whittaker lives and operates. The person who approaches Ivy and asks the questions should be someone curious about sabotage; given the easy-to-digest nature of the questions, this person might be a detective, but it would be better for the secondary character to be related to the setting. So Ivy will be approached by a housemaid, who wants to understand the sabotage better, but Ivy, compelled by her personality, will continually belittle the maid, and try to manipulate her into helping her with her next sabotage attempt, while answering her questions. The setting will be tense, as the maid tiptoes around the tempers of her mistress while trying to get her questions answered, her stress and the constant wear of Ivy's cruelty on her psyche being evident in her actions. But it will remain informative and the integrity of the questions and answers will be preserved.
Step 5. Interaction: Given these constraints, the first message might be Ivy coldly asking what the maid wants from her (Ivy may throw in a spiteful remark about the maid's past work, given her uncompromising nature). The maid's response might then be a deferential attempt to calm Ivy down, followed by the first question. Ivy will then provide the first answer, though she will surround the answer with boasts and belittling remarks due to her personality. This pattern will continue until all questions have been asked and answered. While characters' messages will include character information, details about the scene, and literary fluff, the answers themselves will strictly adhere to the information in the provided answers, without incorporating external examples.
